facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 471 of 1963 filed by appellant.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 471 of 1963.

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from judgment and decree dated November 9, 1960 of Punjab High Court in Regular Second Appeal No. 1627 of 1960.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and decree dated November 9- 1960 of the Punjab High. Court in Regular Second Appeal No. 1627 of 1960.

facts.text: Punjab High Court dismissed appellant's appeal in limine.

anchor.surface_text: from a judgment of the High Court of Punjab dismissing the appellants appeal in limine is whether the suit for possession

facts.text: Appellant has a share of 1221/143 1/2 in the land in suit.

anchor.surface_text: The facts which are number disputed before us are briefly these The appellant has a share of 1221/143 1/2 in the land in suit.

facts.text: Occupancy tenant of the land is Akhara Nirbansar of Sultanwind Gate, Amritsar.

anchor.surface_text: The occupancy tenant of this land is Akhara Nirbansar of Sultanwind Gate, Amritsar.

facts.text: Ram Saran Das was Mahant of Akhara till 1950, removed by civil court order in suit under s.92 CPC, confirmed on appeal on September 11, 1950.

anchor.surface_text: The second respondent Ram Saran Das was Mahant of this Akhara till the year 1950 when he was removed by virtue of an order made by a civil companyrt in a suit under s. 92 of the Code of Civil Procedure, companyfirmed in appeal on September 11, 1950.

facts.text: Respondent No.1 Amardas appointed as Mahant on December 29, 1953.

anchor.surface_text: On December 29, 1953 respondent No. 1 was appointed as Mahant in place of respondent No. 2.

facts.text: Appellant instituted suit on September 15, 1939 in revenue court under ss.38 and 39 of Punjab Tenancy Act for possession of 141 kanals 8 marlas of land.

anchor.surface_text: On September 15, 1939 the appellant instituted a suit in a revenue companyrt under ss. 38 and 39 of the Punjab Tenancy Act  hereafter referred to as the Act  for possession of 141 kanals 8 marlas of land

facts.text: Revenue Court decreed ejectment of portion dug up on June 3, 1940.

anchor.surface_text: The Revenue Court held that out of the land sub-leased by respondent No. 2 only a certain portion was dug up by the sub-lessee and, therefore, the ejectment of the second respondent was companyfined to that area of land which had been dug up. The date of the ejectment decree was June 3, 1940.

facts.text: Collector's appeal dismissal on October 19, 1940.

anchor.surface_text: The second respondent preferred an appeal before the Collector from that decree which was dismissed on October 19, 1940.

facts.text: Appellant obtained possession shortly after October 19, 1940 decree.

anchor.surface_text: Shortly thereafter the appellant obtained possession of the land from which the second respondent was ordered to be ejected.

facts.text: Second suit by appellant for ejectment of remaining land after continued digging.

anchor.surface_text: The lessee of the second respondent, however, companytinued to dig up the rest of the land and, therefore, the appellant instituted a second suit for the ejectment of the second respondent therefrom.

facts.text: Assistant Collector decreed ejectment of entire remaining land.

anchor.surface_text: The Assistant Collector who tried the suit granted a decree to the appellant in respect of the entire land which was left with the second respondent after he was dispossessed from a part of the land leased to him under the earlier decree.

facts.text: Collector modified ejectment order on May 31, 1943, leaving out 29 kanals 14 marlas.

anchor.surface_text: In appeal, however, the Collector modified the order of ejectment by leaving out of the land 29 kanals and 14 marlas. This order was made on May 31, 1943.

facts.text: Appellant obtained possession of confirmed ejectment land shortly after May 31, 1943.

anchor.surface_text: Shortly thereafter the appellant obtained possession of the land with respect to which the Collector had companyfirmed the order of ejectment in the appeal.

facts.text: Respondent No.1 instituted suit against appellant and second respondent on March 18, 1957.

anchor.surface_text: On March, 18, 1957 the first respondent instituted a suit against the appellant and the second respondent.

facts.text: Trial court decreed suit in favour of respondent No.1.

anchor.surface_text: The suit was decreed by the trial companyrt and its decision was unheld in appeal by the second Additional District Judge, Amritsar.

facts.text: Decision upheld by second Additional District Judge, Amritsar.

anchor.surface_text: The suit was decreed by the trial companyrt and its decision was unheld in appeal by the second Additional District Judge, Amritsar.

facts.text: Appellant in continuous possession of land for more than 12 years before suit as owner.

anchor.surface_text: The second point was that as the appellant was in companytinuous possession of the land in suit as owner in his own right for more than 12 years preceding the suit openly and to the exclusion of the second respondent and respondent No. 1 the suit was barred by time.

facts.text: Respondent No.1 claims land is wakf property of Akhara, actions of Ram Saran Das unauthorised alienation.

anchor.surface_text: According to respondent No. 1 Akhara Nirbansar was number bound by the actions of Mahant Ram Saran Das, the second respondent, which were tantamount to alienation of the land which, according to him, were neither for legal necessity number for the benefit of the estate.

facts.text: Occupancy rights extinguished by revenue court decrees.

anchor.surface_text: He denied that the land was wakf property and companytended that the occupancy rights existing in favour of the second respondent were extinguished by the orders of the revenue companyrts which still hold good.

facts.text: Facts of appellant's possession over 12 years not disputed by respondent No.1.

anchor.surface_text: As pointed out by the learned Solicitor General, respondent No. 1 in his replication has number disputed the fact that the appellant was in possession for more than 12 years before the institution of the suit

facts.text: Eviction of respondent No.2 in 1940 and 1943 led to merger of occupancy rights into appellant's ownership.

anchor.surface_text: It seems to us clear that upon the eviction of respondent No. 2 from a part of the land in the year 1940 and the rest of it in the year 1943 the occupancy right with respect to the land merged in the right of ownership of the appellant.

facts.text: Appellant in actual physical possession continuously for more than 12 years before suit.

anchor.surface_text: Apart from that it is clear that the actual physical possession of the land having been companytinuously with the appellant to the exclusion of the occupancy tenant, whether it was respondent No. 1 or the Akhara itself. for a period more than 12 years before the institution of the suit that right was extinguished.

facts.text: Ejectment was forfeiture of tenancy, not alienation.

anchor.surface_text: The simple answer to this companytention is that what happened in this case was the forfeiture of the occupancy tenancy by the appellant as landlord. In numbersense can this be regarded as, or even likened to alienation

arguments.claim: Land in question was never attached to the Akhara; Mahant Ram Saran Das was its occupancy tenant; sub-lessee dug up land rendering unfit; entitled to eject by forfeiting lease; land not wakf; occupancy rights extinguished by revenue court orders

anchor.surface_text: The first was that the land in question was never attached to the Akhara but that Mahant Ram Saran Das, the second respondent, was its occupancy tenant and that as the sub- lessee of the land had dug it up and rendered it unfit for cultivation the appellant as the owner of the land was entitled to eject respondent No. 2 by forfeiting the lease. He denied that the land was wakf property and contended that the occupancy rights existing in favour of the second respondent were extinguished by the orders of the revenue courts which still hold good.

precedents.citation: Dwijendra Narain Roy v. Joges Chandra De 1

precedents.case_name: Dwijendra Narain Roy v Joges Chandra De
precedents.cited_proposition: time runs when the cause of action accrues, and a cause of action accrues when there is in existence a person who can sue and another who can be sued; the cause of action arises when the aggrieved party has the right to apply to the proper tribunals for relief; statute of limitation does not run until there is a right of action

anchor.surface_text: considered in this appeal by special leave from a judgment of the High Court of Punjab dismissing the appellants appeal in limine is whether the suit for possession instituted by the plaintiff-respondent No. 1 is within time.

It seems to us clear that upon the eviction of respondent No. 2 from a part of the land in the year 1940 and the rest of it in the year 1943 the occupancy right with respect to the land merged in the right of ownership of the appellant. Apart from that it is clear that the actual physical possession of the land having been continuously with the appellant to the exclusion of the occupancy tenant, whether it was respondent No. 1 or the Akhara itself. for a period more than 12 years before the institution of the suit that right was extinguished.

anchor.surface_text: We may point out that a Mahant of an Akhara represents the Akhara and has both the right to institute a suit on its behalf as also the duty to defend one brought against it.

It seems to us clear that upon the eviction of respondent No. 2 from a part of the land in the year 1940 and the rest of it in the year 1943 the occupancy right with respect to the land merged in the right of ownership of the appellant. Apart from that it is clear that the actual physical possession of the land having been continuously with the appellant to the exclusion of the occupancy tenant, whether it was respondent No. 1 or the Akhara itself. for a period more than 12 years before the institution of the suit that right was extinguished.
